results.title: Walk - Walk - Walk
results.brief_description: In 1966 Paul was playing in a band, ‘The Castaways’, the next minute he was conscripted to service in Vietnam. When Paul arrived in Vietnam he was told, “You’re in the infantry now, you will walk, and walk, and walk some more. You had to keep on moving, that was how you got through.”

results.title: The Empty nest
results.creator_credit: Judith Kress, Jonathan Kress and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Tells of the threat of extinction to the osprey (fish hawk); since 1950, 90% of these birds have vanished due to the effects of pesticides. Studies the bird’s courtship, rearing of young, flight patterns and habits. Tells of the effects of pesticides in relation to the food chain.

results.title: The Empty frame
results.brief_description: The biography of Robert Goddard and the history of the development of rocketry. Shows how Goddard’s research and developmental work, with respect to rocketry, made possible the great space exploration vehicles of today. Includes archival footage

results.title: Blues for a red planet
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Richard Wells, Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Mars has fascinated humans for centuries, and become the mythic arena on to which we have projected our earthly hopes and fears. In this program Carl Sagan begins with H. G. Wells’ vision of Martians, shows us the telescope through which Lowell studied the “canals” on Mars, touches on Robert Goddard’s experiments with rockets and looks in depth at the Viking landers and their observational role. He concludes by discussing the possibility of microbiotic life and the potential for future colonisation of “the Red Planet”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Richard Wells, Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)

results.title: Journeys in space and time
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan explores the relationship of space and time. He begins by showing how the shape of the constellations would change over millions of years, as the stars move and evolve, and then launches into a discussion on the speed of light and Einstein’s theory of relativity, concluding with the tantalising possibilities of time travel and parallel universes.

results.title: One voice in the cosmic fugue
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, Polytel, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Carl Sagan explores the nature of life on earth from its earliest beginnings to the present. The use of computer animation vividly explains evolution and the structure of the cell and DNA, and the real-life example of the Japanese Heike crab whose form has gradually changed through human intervention, demonstrates the process of artificial selection. Although human life is but one branch of the evolutionary tree we are now influencing all other branches. Sagan concludes by speculating on different paths that evolution may take on other worlds with quite different environments.

results.title: The Emperor and the nightingale
results.creator_credit: Mark Sottnick, Joel Tuber, Windham Hill and Rabbit Ears Productions
results.brief_description: Glenn Close narrates Hans Christian Andersen’s story of the Chinese emperor who discovers that the song of a free nightingale, is more beautiful and more valuable by far, than the finest and cleverest, bejewelled mechanical singing bird. The exquisite illustrations are by Robert Van Nutt and the evocative music is by Mark Isham.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Sottnick, Joel Tuber, Windham Hill and Rabbit Ears Productions
results.description: Glenn Close narrates Hans Christian Andersen’s story of the Chinese emperor who discovers that the song of a free nightingale, is more beautiful and more valuable by far, than the finest and cleverest, bejewelled mechanical singing bird. The exquisite illustrations are by Robert Van Nutt and the evocative music is by Mark Isham.

results.title: The Shores of the cosmic ocean
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, Rob McCain, Polytel, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
From the shores of the great ocean of space, Carl Sagan begins his contemplation of the universe. His aim is to find out how we achieved our understanding of the cosmos, how the cosmos shaped us and what is its future. A tour of the universe is followed by a detailed look at the library of Alexandria, where the intellectual adventure which led us into space began. The program concludes with Sagan’s “cosmic calendar” to make comprehensible the vast expanse of time from the Big Bang to the present.

results.title: The Harmony of the worlds
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
All over the world, our ancestors in every culture taught themselves astronomy. Their lives quite literally depended on it. But the journey from the earliest astronomers to the modern day detoured into the pseudo-science of astrology. The last scientific astrologer, was also the first modern astronomer: Johannes Kepler, and this program looks at Kepler’s struggle to find a harmony in the heavens, in the process making the critical step which was to move us into the scientific age.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
